awd_titl_txt: Graph Theoretical Methods for Blockchain Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Graph Theoretical Methods for Blockchain Data Analysis Workshop, May 25, 2022 George Mason University

The Workshop on Graph Theoretical Methods for Blockchain Data Analysis will be focused on the recent developments on the foundational statistical and mathematical tools associated with the data structures that arise from the use of distributed secure ledger technologies.  Building on the efforts of the first conference, the second workshop will bring together researchers from a broad range of mathematical and statistical disciplines, from graph theory to computational topology to mathematical statistics, to discuss the open problems in analysis, modeling and inference for this class of data in an open forum. While the goal of the second workshop is focused on the mathematical sciences community, we will also include select researchers in e-crime detection, cryptocurrency risk analysis, integration of private and public blockchains, and other distributed ledger-based applications to calibrate the mathematical scientists on the needs of this community. 

The Workshop on Graph Theoretical Methods for Blockchain Data Analysis will address issues related to the new blockchain technology. Blockchain has already revolutionized many fields, from e-payments to digital ownership management, enabling organizations to leverage a secure distributed public ledger. The first popular application of blockchain was the Bitcoin cryptocurrency, and since then blockchain technology has witnessed rapid evolution and unprecedented interest, from investors to regulating agencies to the general public. For instance, most recent versions of public blockchains such as Ethereum are now used to support fundraising activities for many start-ups by enabling the sales of digital assets worth billions of dollars, to trace the life cycles of crops and other agricultural products, from seed to consumers, determining the responsibilities of each party within the supply chain, and to validate compliance protocols and transparency of clinical trials. As more blockchain applications and variations of the original algorithms are developed and deployed, novel interdisciplinary tools for blockchain data analytics are of critical importance for enhancing our understanding of the emerging phenomena and a wide range of its societal impacts, from energy sharing during natural disasters to novel methods for secure access of electronic health information.  This workshop will bring together researchers in the mathematical sciences to address the needs of this rapidly evolving community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This grant was intended to support a conference where members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the broader intelligence community as well as members of the Algorithms for Threat Detection (ATD) community and researchers could all have access to the current state of blockchain data analysis. We worked closely with a former program manager to organize the conference with the ATD community. The conference was completed before the grant was awarded. The original conference was proposed to take place in the spring of 2022. By April 1st, 2022, we had not heard any word on the funding sources for the proposed conference so we worked with the prior programming manager of ATD to reshuffle the blockchain data analysis workshop and combine it to a joint online/in-person meeting with the 2022 ATD workshop. South Dakota State University (SDSU) supported the PI, Dr. Chris Saunders to help with the onsite organization of the meeting and supported five graduate students to host and organize an online zoom sequence of the meeting. 

There were a number of people from the Department of Justice (DOJ) and private sector attending the meeting both online and in-person who were interested not only in the blockchain component but also the forensic component of the manifold learning aspects of the ATD program. Of particular importance was Dr. Gregory Dutton of the National Institute Justice (NIJ) and Dr. Charles Twardy of Jacobs Solutions. At a later date, Dr. Saunders was informed that the Division of Mathematical Sciences had decided to award the grant, and with discussion with the prior program manager, we decided to have a series of follow-on meetings with specific individuals related to the broader ATD portfolio. The remaining funds with supplementary funds from SDSU were used to support a master’s student, Mr. Cole Patten, to reach out to the presenters of the conference to collate their abstracts and presentation slides into the fall semester. 

In terms of conference attendees, there were over fourty total attendees both over Zoom and in-person. While small for a non-covid year, we were pleased with the attendance at that stage in the pandemic. The specific number of attendees for the blockchain workshop is unclear due to the heavy overlap for the ATD PIs and the researchers we were recruiting for the blockchain workshop. Below is the complete list of people invited to the joint workshop. The complete list of presenters will be available for the ATD report on the workshop. We had half a day of presentations focused on graph-based methods for “Graph Theoretical Methods for Blockchain Data Analysis”. There are a number of people who presented specifically on the graph-based methods, the titles of talks associated with the workshop are below corresponding with the lead authors. 

In terms of broader impacts and follow-on efforts, a series of online meetings were held with SDSU, members of the FBI, and the ATD program manager, to continue discussions about transitioning methods developed under the ATD portfolio to support the needs of the broadly defined forensic sciences community. The methods that looked the easiest to transition were the manifold learning methods that had been developed over the years. With the help of the ATD program manager, Dr. Saunders and Dr. Mike Smith of the FBI met with Dr. Michael Kirby of Colorado State University to learn more about these methods. 

Shortly after this, we lost contact with Dr. Leland Jameson. In early 2023, Dr. Saunders, in collaboration with researchers at the FBI Labs, proposed a session theme on the intersection of forensic inference and manifold learning, of which we invited a number of ATD PIs or students trained by ATD PIs. This conference is expected to be held in June 2023. Dr. Saunders will reach back to the current program manager to discuss any possible developments from this upcoming conference. 



 

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2023
Modified by: Cami M Fuglsby
